doc_id: BLS T2_Traumatic Emergencies- Chest and Abdomen_March 2020

pages.text:
March 2020 County of Marin EMS BLS T2
TRAUMATIC EMERGENCIES-
CHEST AND ABDOMEN
Indications
• Patient with a traumatic injury to the chest and/or abdomen
BLS RMC
Spinal immobilization if indicated
• Control bleeding
• Prevent further injuries
Prepare for early and rapid transport to the appropriate facility
Tension Pneumothorax Flail or Crushed Chest Evisceration of
Abdomen
• Fowlers position • Splint chest wall with
unless contraindicated bulky dressing or towel • Cover abdominal
• Remove occlusive if flail chest wound with moist,
dressing if present • Assist with positive bulky dressing
pressure ventilations • Keep patient warm
Pelvic Instability Open/Sucking Chest
Wound
• Immobilize
• Fowlers position
unless contraindicated
• Occlusive dressing if
SPECIAL CONSIDERATION sucking wound
• Monitor for tension
• Patients meeting anatomic, physiologic, high
pneumothorax
energy transfer, and other mechanism of injury
on the Marin County Trauma Triage Tool
should be transported with ALS level of care
